title: CTRL0000071084 - Transcribed Interview of David Millard, (Apr. 18, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF: DAVID MATTHEW MILLARD
Monday, April 18, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held 5480 O'Neill HOB, commencing at
Members Present:
Representatives Schiff.

For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE

Good afternoon.
This is a transcribed interview of Sergeant David Millard
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time.

yourself.

Operation Noble Eagle, Fort Jackson, South Carolina.
investigative experience, also joined the special reaction team while I was down

doing EPOW operations -- enemy prisoner of war operations -- in -- in a couple of the jail

Police and began training in January of 2005.

I will save all my Army jokes for

Police?

My father

homicide.
mother is a civilian.

Family of law enforcement.

associate's degree.
the Park Police, who wasn't hiring at the time; U.S. Marshals, who were currently in a

towards a federal path as far as me not going --

My mother forbid me to work for the Secret Service, and that left

My father directed me

So I only heard the jobs that you were considering, even after the high

It was intentional, yes.

And just help us explain -- right -- so you're 18 leaving high school, you go

Yes.
I guess, what did that mean to you even at an early age?
While I did ROTC in high school, and I had ROTC instructors that were
all infantry, Special Forces, Ranger type people that were, you know, retired, and were
people that I followed through high school.
idea of joining the military, they just always said if you have the option to never walk
anywhere, don't do so, which led -- led to a couple of different careers.
I had a mechanical mindset.
And when I began discussing with them the
I liked doing things, such as maintenance, but
those -- thinking long term where I could end up after the military, the military police and
law enforcement was a viable career, so that's the route that I ended up going.

And you became an MP, right?
A
Yes.
Q
Can you walk us through -- so you've been in Capitol Police from 2005 until
currently in 2022?
A
Until current, yes.

So can you walk through -- and it can just be high level --
A
Sure.
Q
But walk us through the positions you've held in Capitol Police from 2005
until 2022 -- well, right before January 6th?
Sure.
A
So 2005, I was -- went to Federal Law Enforcement Training Center in
Georgia for mixed basic police training program.
Completed that in June of '05.
Went
to midnights at the Capitol division, as my first assignment.
probation.
uniform in plain clothes element of the Capitol Police that provides protection for the
House Chamber, specifically.
Did that for a year for
Completed probation, and signed up for the House Chambers, which is the
I did that for about three months, and then was accepted into our dignatory

Shortly thereafter, in late 2007 -- I don't -- I don't have the exact
date, but permanently assigned to dignatory protection at the then Minority Whip of the
Senate detail.
Minority Whip detail, did eight years with that protectee.
was eventually assigned to become an instructor and trainer for dignatory protection.
Completed that detail when the Member retired.
Stayed with the
Throughout that time, I -- I
Once that protectee and that detail ended, I ended up on the Speaker's protection
detail.
I did that for three years until his retirement.
Then transitioned over to threat
assessment as investigation -- investigator.
Georgia, for criminal investigation training program, and was in that position for about a
year and a half.
Went into investigations, went back FLETC,
And then got promoted in 2016, I believe, 2016.
Became sergeant,
and was assigned to the Senate detail as an official.
I was there for approximately two months -- two and a half, maybe three months,
before a threat protection detail was established for a U.S. Senator.
assigned as -- as a supervisor for that protection detail, which lasted about 18 months.
And then I was
Once that detail ended roughly October 2018, I was then assigned to the criminal
investigations section within the investigations division as their official over CIS.
Q
And right before 2021, were you serving in the inauguration task force?
A
I was.
So roughly May, June of 2020, was assigned to the inauguration task
force full time where -- where our goal was to prepare for the Presidential
inauguration -- the upcoming Presidential inauguration, and I held many primary roles
within that task force.
Q
Can you just give us -- and - m a y come in and ask more follow-up,
but I'm going to start off this line of questioning -- kind of the trainings you completed
that were relevant, in particular, in responding to January 6th?
you -- did you take as an -- as an officer?
A
So what trainings did
Through the -- through military police school, we had civil disturbance
training that -- that was primarily focused around the law enforcement mission or military
enforcement mission of prison -- prison missions and riots.
I had experience in Iraq with that.
My battalion was assigned to Abu Ghraib and
a couple of the other Baghdad prisons, so whenever they had uprisings, our
company -- our headquarters company would respond to reenforce the staff at those
prisons.
So I've had experience with -- with similar activity.
Basic law enforcement at U.S. Capitol Police Academy.
we do a week of civil disturbance training.
was the last time that I did civil disturbance training.
Following the academy,
That, for me, was in June of 2005, and that
Q
So in your roles on protection details, like for the Senate Whip or the
Speaker, that's a different set of skills than maybe civil disturbance-type skill sets; is that
fair?
A
Yes.
_ , did you have any follow-up on trainings, in
particular?
No, not -- not at this time.
BY
Thank you.
Q
Thank you.
So then let's fast forward.
I know you joined -- it sounds like
the inauguration task force in May or June of 2020.
A
Yes.
Q
You didn't have to work or respond to any rally, I guess, leading up to

A
I did not.
Q
Okay.
In the days leading up to January 6th, do you recall any briefings or meetings you
So then let's -- let's go straight to January 6th or the days before.
attended particularly about January 6th?
why I just want to make sure we know.
A
I know you were on the task force, so that's
So through the inauguration task force, one of my primary responsibilities
was the Intelligence Subcommittee for the inauguration.
were an FBI and Secret Service agent and Capitol Police were participants for the

meetings that were supposed to begin in July, but really did not begin until much later in
the year.
That -- the committee chairs
I was principally responsible for attending the
COVID really put a -- a damper on the planning.
As time started getting closer towards January, started pushing for more meetings
and eventually, the subcommittee held meetings for -- for -- the Intelligence
Subcommittee held meetings virtually.

So this Intelligence Subcommittee, did it -- who did it compose of it?
A
Most of the federal agencies within the National Capital Region.
chairs were FBI and Secret Service.
it was represented by 30-some odd agencies -- D.C.

Capitol Police was there, Supreme Court.
Again, two
I mean,
Metropolitan Police.
But it was led by -- and when I said "led," at least the two chairs
were FBI and Secret Service?
A
Correct.

And when did, I guess, these meetings -- you said later on in the year, as you
approached -- but when did they really start to become more regular, if they became
regular?
A
I'd say August.
Q
August.
A
Is when we began having -- having frequent meetings, monthly, and then
they eventually became biweekly.
Q
And were events, such as the rallies held in support of former President
Trump in November and December, were those topics during these meetings?
A
They were, yes.
Q
What do you recall being discussed about these two events in particular?
A
These two particular events -- the inauguration was always not a topic,
which, for me, it caused -- my focus was for the inauguration.
being used for situational updates and intelligence updates for whatever major event was
taking place in the city at the time.
These meetings were
I remember a lot of the preceding meetings prior to the one just before
January 6th always covering the demonstration or the protest that had just occurred,
whether it was the MAGA 1 or 2 rally, or the -- the Black Lives Matter protest.
always a follow-up or a recap to what took place during the preceding rally.
It was
And do you recall, though, I guess -- so it's -- it was a follow-up, almost like a
Q
debrief?
A
Yes.
Q
Okay.
Do you recall anything of note that came out of the debriefing
meetings from -- you refer to them --1 assume November and December is MAGA 1 and
MAGA 2 rallies?
A
Yes.
Q
Do you recall anything of note coming out of those debriefings?
A
They talked about the violence that had occurred and they talked about the
conflicts between the opposing groups and the number of people arrested and the
number of injuries that occurred.
discussing the number of arrests and the number of people that were assaulted during
the event.
The -- the last meeting prior to January 6th, they were
Those numbers were -- were relatively low from what I recall.
It was just information sharing.
There were people in the room that would ask
questions, such as number of arrests, describing what was taking place during the events,
but it was -- there -- none of the information was a -- was for the following event or for
the upcoming event.
Q
Do you recall -- it sounds like the debriefing was mostly about protester,
counter-protester type violence?
A
Yes.
Q
So it wasn't really about any actors being violent or actions towards law
enforcement; is that fair?
A
They talked about skirmishes with law enforcement, but the primary or the
principal conflicts were surrounding around law enforcement keeping the opposing
factions apart.
not that I can recall.
Q
It was never a, these people are here to target law enforcement, at least
So with that in mind, what were your expectations heading into January 6th?
Like, what were you thinking that day was going to be?
A
The last meeting was -- was somewhat unusual, just there was a
speaker -- and I don't recall exactly, but I believe it was a person from the DCH SEMA,
who said, I'm a little worried about this one because we're seeing information that there
are going to be more groups coming, and there were going to be more groups that were
intending to cause conflict with violence and potential for weapons to be drawn.
Q
Where was this person from --
A
1 believe it was DCH SEMA, which is the Homeland Security Emergency
Management Committee.
I believe that was his title as he spoke.
But it stood out to me because it prompted me to get in touch with our TFO,
who's -- who sits on the same squad with the FBI chair to say, hey, are you guys tracking
whatever information it is that is, you know, prompting these additional concerns?
Q
What does a TFO stand for?
A
Task -- task force officer.
Q
Task force officer.
A
These are Capitol Police agents that are assigned to various task forces
A threat --
through the FBI and the Secret Service.
Q
So you reached out to your TFO within the Inauguration Committee?
A
So he was also -- he was also a participant within the Inauguration
Committee, and I just happened to know him.
We were in recruit class together, so he
was somebody that I could -- I could easily call to have a conversation with.
Q
individual?
A
And when do you recall this meeting with the Homeland Security D.C.
Do you recall what date this was on?
I don't recall, but it was the weekend -- the weekend.
It was the weekday
prior to the weekend before January 6th, so it was several days.
Q
With the holidays, right?
A
Yes.
Q
It was the last workday technically before the week of January 6th?
A
Correct, yeah.
The Reporter.
Yes, go ahead.
The Reporter.
I'm sorry.
It just --
We can take a quick recess in place.
Can I --

will turn it over t o - .
We can't hear you.
We can't hear you.
You're on m u t e , - ·
Q
Sorry about that.
Sergeant, I had one question.
When you mentioned
that you were a part of those task forces there, and listening to the briefings up until
January 6th, and the inauguration, you said the main focus was not on the inauguration
there, but just other, I guess, protests that happened prior to then, and discussing the
briefing information concerning those protests.
My question is this.
Was there any information that you had learned from the
previous protests that could potentially assist and/or help before the inauguration and/or
the incident on January the 6th that you passed along to higher ups or anybody within
your shop?
A
No, sir.
Specifically for January 6th, that was not a topic.
We were in hold
mode until the actual election -- the election was determined -- or we were waiting for
the outcome of the election to actually start making concrete plans about January 6th.
The information for -- I'm sorry
-- about the inauguration.
The information that was provided, which was the same for all of the preceding
meetings, which was there were no significant or credible threats directed at the
inauguration or the event itself or to the NCR.
That was always the outcome or the
disposition from the intelligence side of things.
But then the gathering was used to
highlight the updates and the debrief from the previous events.
Q
I'm more focused or at least asking the question from the standpoint of this:
Tactically, from your experience being there on several different protective details, was
there anything that you may have heard in those briefings that the protesters were doing
that could have assisted in the planning or whatever for events there on January the 6th
and/or as the inauguration to kind of help bolster the security, and, again, was that
information passed up?
A
these meetings.
Q
No, sir, there was never any actionable information during these -- during
So there was no -- there was no discussion of the amount of protesters
that were at these previous rallies and how they were interacting with police or
interacting with other individuals out in the crowd, as far as pro or against whatever the
rally supported?
A
No, not to any specificity.
Q
Okay.
All right.
No, sir.
A
One thing -- one thing that was covered, as an alibi to this, they did discuss
hotel occupancy in the area.
shared by Metropolitan through their resources.
time period centered around these protests -- how many hotels in the region were
occupied and what their staffing was, and it was never anything at 100 percent.
always, you know, 40, 50, 60 -- normal for the -- for the time period.
Q
So that was another piece of the intelligence that was
As far as identifying -- you know, the
It was
For your position that you held at that time, and the information that you
were looking at gathering for the Capitol Police, what information -- what would have
been that information to help support what you were doing?
A
The question does make sense.
Does that make sense?
So why were we having these meetings,
and that was a good question.
Q
For -- for Capitol Police.
A
For Capitol Police or for the group itself to be centered around the
inauguration, and I had a conversation with the chair separately to ask about these intel
meetings, and if this was a normal thing that the inauguration just happened to be a part
of, or were these meetings somehow now occurring because of the inauguration.
And my understanding is, is that the intelligence group that was gathered was
taking advantage of this planned time for inauguration planning to also discuss events
that were occurring relevant to the time period we were in the meetings.
The inauguration planning portion for it -- again, because of COVID -- and I hate
using this as an excuse as everybody else hates hearing it.
But we really could not make
any -- any decisions on what was needed.
hash out manpower requirements surrounding what was known for inaugural planning.
The number of agencies that we would be bringing in, uniform -- because, if you recall
previous inaugurations, we bring in uniformed officers from throughout the country to
So the purpose of these meetings were to
help support the million-person gathering that's normal for the inauguration.
Well, COVID has kind of put a pause on all of this planning because, again, cities
were still on lock down, major events were not occurring.
But, if we remember, right
around that October, November time frame, numbers were, once again, starting to dip,
so there was still consideration on whether or not an inauguration was going to take
place and it was going to be in person or not.
So that really -- that was really the driving factor around the conversation
surrounding all of the intelligence, which is, hey, from a law enforcement perspective,
these are the resources we would be needing to be bring into play; what would the FBI be
giving to support Capitol Police; what would Secret Service be giving to support Capitol
Police for the even taking place on our grounds.
And none of that was occurring because we didn't actually know what the event
was going to look like, and even leading up to that last week in December, going into
January, we still did not have an answer for what was going to take place three or four
weeks from then.
_ , I just want to step in to say that Representative
Adam Schiff has joined.
and back to you,

Q
I just want to make that for the -- make it clear for the record,
And -- and I see your point as far as the planning piece as far as numbers.
More than anything, I was trying to get your perspective as far as, tactically, looking or
listening to the briefs from the previous -- the previous protest or rallies, how did

didn't -- you couldn't get the numbers and figure out a number of how many people that
you need.
But, tactically, up on Capitol Hill, as far as assets or anything else you may
have needed, how does it impact that?
A
It -- the meetings did not impact any determination for this.
I was not
carrying forward and the Capitol Police team was not carrying forth any information that
would have been actionable by -- by our commanders -- by our command staff.
just -- it wasn't -- it wasn't present.
It
And, I mean, the gatherings that were occurring -- the protests and the
demonstrations that were occurring wasn't -- they weren't major rallies, like what
was -- what was scheduled for January 6th.
just detailing the skirmishes that were occurring between the different groups and the
outcome of arrests and injuries from the confrontations.
Q
So some of that information would not have been vital to you preparing and
outlaying plans for the Capitol either on the 6th and/or doing it for the inauguration?
A
That's correct.
Q
Okay.
A
Thank you, sir.
Good deal.
Thank you.
Thank y o u , - .

So the information leading up to them was
Q
You also mentioned, Sergeant Millard, that during these briefings, you were
receiving reports of more groups -- I think is the term you used -- that might be coming to
the city for January 6th, and had the potential for conflict.
you just explain what you were receiving reports about?
A
What does that mean, or can
So the -- the reports that were highlighted were that there were groups
opposed to the election results that were looking to come to this rally, and those -- those
groups -- these people were intending to travel.
Masked gatherings weren't really occurring, so that was a highlight in and of itself that,
Again, we were in the middle of COVID.
hey, there are actually going to be people that are planning to come to the District, and
that these numbers are going to be bigger than what we've seen in the preceding year,
which was next to nothing due to the public health emergency.
Q
So the reports that you were receiving, it was -- and I'm comparing it to
some of the earlier debriefings where it was counter-protester and protester -- this one
was individuals opposed to the election results.
for you?
A
Yes.
Q
And so getting back to the original question, what was your expectation
Is that kind of how it was highlighted
heading into January 6th having received these reports?
A
My expectation was that there was going to be an event that took place.
There -- everything was very generalized, like there was going to be a protest, there was
going to be a rally, they're here to protest the election results.
You know, there was this -- there was other talks of groups potentially being
armed from militia-type groups that would potentially try to enter the city to participate
in these events.
are politically aligned with certain aspects that want to attend these similarly themed
rallies or protests.
It's always been a thing where you have militia groups that, you know,
So for us it's always, okay, if they're going to come into the city with weapons, you
know, before they get to the Capitol, they have to actually enter the city, and that's
not -- that's not principally a U.S. Capitol Police responsibility.
Metropolitan Police or even federal authorities to determine if these people are actually
coming and if they are actually bringing weapons.
Q
That's going to be on
So, I guess, what was your personal reaction to the thought of individuals
possibly bringing weapons in the city on January 6th?
A
It wasn't the first time that I had heard similar type groups wanting to come
to D.C. to -- to protest and demonstrate in that matter.
be crazy, because if you have weapons, you know what the laws are in the District of
Columbia, and that's -- from a law enforcement reaction perspective, you see somebody
with a weapon, I mean, you're -- you're going to take law enforcement action to it.
not a matter of do you allow it or not.
probable cause if you have people with guns within the city that aren't law enforcement,
you know, that's -- that's a felony.
I always thought that it would
It's
Like, you don't -- you no longer have to establish
So my reaction to it is, it wasn't the first time hearing this, but there was no
further information that established it, beyond any -- this is social media chatter, this is
on line chatter, this is -- that indicated that, you know, there were intelligence sources
involved that gave this any credibility.
Q
So let's then go to January 6th.
A
Yes.
Q
Where were you that morning?
A
Assigned to the ITF.
Q
And that's the inauguration task --
A
Inauguration task force.
500 North Capitol.
building working on my other primary tasks, watching the social media, listening to
the radio -- our Capitol Police radio, and really just started just monitoring for the day.
What was supposed to be a long 24- to 36-hour operational period for the department?
We were expecting Congress to be in session for overnight at this point to handle the
certification.
Q
Where did you report for duty?
We were housed out of the GPO Building off of
I parked in -- parked where I normally parked, and was at the
And just for the record, Mr. Schiff is no longer in the room.
But so you all were expecting for it to be, I mean, possibly an overnight kind of
congressional session?
A
Leading up to the Joint Session beginning, we knew that there were
approximately a dozen challenges to the election results.
nobody yields back any time, that takes the process overnight into following day.
And simple mathematics -- if
So having been at the department 17 years, you automatically know that if
Congress is in full session, you're not running your midnight staffing.
You have to
actually hold people over or bring people in early in order to sustain those operations
leading into the overnight hours, because they're in full session.
purposes is a full session for Congress.
more doors open at a minimum.
just not that many people assigned to midnight, so you have to flex that.
flex your day shift and your swing shift staff in order to support those midnight hours.
Joint Session for this
Your staffing requirements -- you have to keep
You have to keep more officers on staff, and there's
Q
So you were not on the Capitol grounds the morning of --
A
1 was not.
You have to
I was primarily focused on working on media credentialing.
My -- my subtask was to coordinate construction -- media construction, credentialing of
the media compound.
Q
For inauguration?
A
For inauguration.
So I was working with the media staff from the House
and Senate galleries, as well as the civilian staff to get names, and conducting name
checks and record checks, and getting people authorized and approved to be in the
compound area to facilitate construction.
Q
And were -- it sounds like you were following the events on social media, but
were you and your colleagues watching the rallies that were taking place on January 6th?
A
